titlestmt.titleproper: Frederick C. and Jeanette R. Hodgdon PapersMS015

publicationstmt.publisher: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-03 10:08:23 -0400.

repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

did.unittitle: Frederick C. and Jeanette R. Hodgdon Papers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized in one series: personal papers.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Material was pulled from the Hodgdon vertical files and UA021 in the summer of 2013 to create a separate collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, biographical essays, a published book, greeting cards, original receipts for silver artifacts, lustre, glass artifacts, furniture, carpets, and pictures the Hodgdons had collected and eventually donated to Tufts, as well as photographs from the late 19th century to 1952. The collection is primarily related to Hodgdon's role as a trustee and the couple's donations to Tufts in the 1950s. It includes correspondence between John A. Cousens and Frederick C. Hodgdon, Jeannette R. Hodgdon's book titled "Collecting Old English Lustre" describing her lustre collection eventually donated to Tufts, as well as photographs of their former residence at 4 Gramercy Place in New York City.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frederick Crosby Hodgdon was born February 8, 1873 in Waltham, Massachusetts. Mr. Hodgdon entered Tufts College in 1890 and graduated in 1894. He was a member of the Delta Tau Delta Fraternity and Phi Beta Kappa. He was elected an alumni trustee in 1923 and a life trustee in 1935. He was also a member of the Board of Visitors. He and his wife Jeannette made a substantial bequest to the College in 1952.

Hodgdon was hired by Edwin Ginn and Company, the publishing house, when he graduated from Tufts. Edwin Ginn was an alumnus of Tufts graduating in 1862. Hodgdon became a partner at the company in 1912 and retired in 1931. He and his wife collected antique furniture, lustre ware, ruby flash glass, and 18th century silver. Many of these items were donated to Tufts in their bequest. They also owned a townhouse at 4 Gramercy Park in New York City. Frederick C. Hodgdon died in 1946.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series includes original correspondence, documents, manuscripts, photographs and prints, belonging to or in regards to Frederick C. and Jeannette Hodgdon. Mr. Hodgdon was a student and later trustee of Tufts University. Most of the material dates from the 1920s to 1952, when Jeannette Hodgdon died and a significant donation was made to Tufts University from the estate. The items are cataloged at the folder level. The letters mostly fall into two categories: those between Tufts University president John A. Cousens from Mr. Hodgdon and, secondly, letters between Leonard Carmichael (president 1938-1953), both Hodgdons, their lawyers and other associates. Included in the papers are original receipts and letters regarding objects that later were donated to Tufts. In addition, there are greeting cards and photographs, negatives, and drawings of the Hodgdon house in Gramercy Park. There is also a copy of a book published by Mrs. Hodgdon.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged into folders organized according to date and correspondent, as well as a separate folder for Mrs. Hodgdon's book, copies of receipts, and one for the photographs and images.

did.unittitle: Correspondence of F.C. Hodgdon and John Cousens and other Tufts associates 1901-1933

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains letters between F.C. Hodgdon and John A. Cousens between 1920 and 1933 as well as biographical essays on Frederick Hodgdon.

did.unittitle: Cousens/Hodgdon correspondence 1933-34 and Carmichael/Hodgdon family letters 1935-1951

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains letters between F.C. Hodgdon and John A. Cousens from 1933 to 1934, and correspondence between Leonard Carmichael and F.C. Hodgdon, Jeannette Hodgdon and attorneys from 1935-1951.

did.unittitle: Correspondence and documents regarding the Hodgdon Estate 1952-1978

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folder contains correspondence regarding the death of Jeannette Hodgdon, original letters and receipts from their antique purchases, correspondence regarding the Hodgdon Estate with Leonard Carmichael, an essay by Frances Leighton about the Hodgdon lustre ware collection, and documents about the disposition of material dating from the 1970s.

did.unittitle: Hodgdon, Jeannette R. (author) Collection Old English Lustre

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains a copy of a book Jeannette R. Hodgdon wrote about her collection of old English lustreware and published in 1937. There are two letters inside the book from the previous owner of the book and by Frances Leighton who wrote an essay on the collection.

did.unittitle: Hodgdon, F.C. copies of receipts and shipment records of antiques 1924-1938

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This folder contains copies of receipts, customs declaration forms, and shipment records for antiques bought by the Hodgdons from 1924-1938.

did.unittitle: Hodgdon, F.C., photographs, glass plate negatives, cards 1890s-1952

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The folder contains 19th and 20th-century photographs, glass plate negatives, greeting cards, and a print. They range in date from the late 19th century to 1952. Many of the images depict the house at 4 Gramercy Park in New York City.
